item.title: News Analysis: Discordant Verdicts on U.S. Forces in Syria: Too Much, or Too Little
item.description: Critics in both parties said President Obama’s decision to send a small team of American commandos into Syria reflected a tactical shift rather than a comprehensive strategy.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: A young victim of an airstrike in Douma, Syria, on Friday by what local activists said were forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad.

item.title: Russian Airliner Crashes in Egypt, Killing 224
item.description: The Kogalymavia flight from the Egyptian resort of Sharm el-Sheikh to St. Petersburg crashed shortly after takeoff, officials said.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR and MERNA THOMAS
item.media:description: Debris from the Russian plane that crashed in Egypt on Saturday.

item.title: Editorial: Chinese Officials Should Stop Trying to Limit Family Size
item.description: Despite the easing of its dictate on family size, Beijing is still in the business of blocking personal freedom.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.media:description: A boy walked with his parents in Shanghai on Friday.

item.title: A Mass Migration Crisis, and It May Yet Get Worse
item.description: The most striking thing about the monumental migration crisis may not be the millions of people on the move now, but rather, the countless others who are poised to follow their paths to Europe.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants walked on top of a dike as they were escorted by Slovenian riot police to the registration camp outside Dobova, Slovenia, on Oct. 23.

item.title: Opinion: On Being Queer in the Caribbean
item.description: To find themselves, and safety, many gay and trans people choose exile.
item.dc:creator: GABRIELLE BELLOT
item.media:description: Andree, the self-proclaimed guardian of the trans and gay youth of Shoemaker Gully in Kingston, Jamaica, says he has lived on the streets for as long as he can remember.

item.title: 2 Men Who Published Writings Critical of Extremism Are Stabbed in Bangladesh
item.description: As “hit lists” of secular writers circulate on the Internet, many writers and journalists have become hesitant to publish work that could attract the attention of Islamists.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Battle Heats Up Over Exports of Surveillance Technology
item.description: Silicon Valley is resisting federal plans to increase regulations on exports of “dual use” technology like servers and software used in social media that can also be used for spying.
item.dc:creator: JAMES RISEN

item.title: German Village of 102 Braces for 750 Asylum Seekers
item.description: Sumte has become a showcase of the extreme pressures bearing down on Germany, and at least one neo-Nazi welcomes the news, if not the refugees.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christian Fabel, the mayor of Sumte, Germany, stands in front of a facility to house migrants from Africa and the Middle East.

item.title: Russian Plane Crashes in Sinai Peninsula
item.description: A Russian airplane crashed early Saturday in the central Sinai Peninsula, according to a statement from the office of Egypt’s prime minister.
item.dc:creator: MERNA THOMAS and NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Cyclone Chapala, Gathering Strength, Heads Toward Oman and Yemen
item.description: The system packed sustained winds of almost 150 miles per hour and threatened to bring dangerous torrential rains to two of the most arid countries in the world.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Netanyahu Retracts Assertion That Palestinian Inspired Holocaust
item.description: After more than a week of condemnation, the Israeli prime minister issued a statement retracting his accusation that a Palestinian cleric had given Hitler the idea of annihilating Jews.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Cemetery in Guyana Is Prepared for Fallen Officer Randolph Holder, a Native Son
item.description: Officer Holder will be buried on Saturday in Le Repentir Cemetery in Guyana, where he played as a child.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MARKS and BENJAMIN MUELLER
item.media:description: Quincy Christian, 33, sits across from the grave site where his friend, Officer Randolph Holder, will be buried on Saturday in Georgetown, Guyana.

item.title: Obama Sends Special Operations Forces to Help Fight ISIS in Syria
item.description: The president announced on Friday that several dozen troops would be deployed to Kurdish-controlled territory for the first open-ended mission by American ground forces in Syria.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER, HELENE COOPER and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: “These forces do not have a combat mission,” Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, said of the troops’ advisory role.

item.title: Deadly Fire Roars Through Romanian Nightclub
item.description: More than two dozen people were killed and scores were injured in the fire that broke out during a rock concert in Bucharest.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:description: Emergency workers outside a nightclub in Bucharest, where a fire killed at least 26 people.

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Murder Inquiry Widens
item.description: A man arrested in the killing of a 4-year-old migrant boy from Bosnia has confessed to killing another child, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: Rare Cyclone Approaches
item.description: A storm gathering in the Arabian Sea was headed for Yemen and Oman and could cause floods, landslides and infrastructure damage.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Malaysia: Maldivians Are Deported
item.description: Five people, including a diplomat, were deported over an alleged attempt to assassinate the Maldivian president.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Norway: Muslim Cleric Sentenced
item.description: The Iraqi-born cleric was given 18 months in jail for praising the killing of cartoonists at the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Israel Restricts Palestinians’ Entry Into Part of Hebron
item.description: The restrictions by Israel followed a spate of stabbings in and around Hebron and also kept young Palestinian men from an Islamic shrine.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: U.S. Tech Giants May Blur National Security Boundaries in China Deals
item.description: A growing number of companies like IBM, Cisco Systems and Microsoft have partnerships with Chinese companies with ties to the military, and experts are questioning those links.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR and JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ted S. Warren, via Reuters
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, front row center, with senior technology company executives at a conference held at Microsoft in Redmond, Wash., in September.
